conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with a hemispherical glass brick and light beams a and b.
Hemispherical glass brick on horizontal plane AB, flat surface upwards, curved surface downwards.
Point C is the midpoint of AB, OO' is perpendicular to AB through C.
Light beams a and b are incident perpendicularly at points equidistant from C.
No refraction at the first surface as the angle of incidence is 0°.
Light beams will refract at the curved surface as they exit the glass.
Understanding diffraction as bending of waves, more pronounced for longer wavelengths.
Relationship between frequency, wavelength, and speed of light: c = λ × f.
In glass, refractive index n = c/v and wavelength in medium λ_medium = λ/n.
Higher frequency corresponds to shorter wavelength, lower frequency to longer wavelength.
In diffraction, longer wavelengths diffract more.
Light b has higher frequency, hence shorter wavelength, should diffract less.
Considering refractive index's dependence on wavelength, higher frequency light bent more.
